desk_notes.day_1: Welcome, {name}. Prove I didn't make a mistake.
day_2: Regionbladet sold 200 more copies yesterday. Step it up.
The competition ran a strong front page. We need to answer.
Day two. This is where we set the tone. Don't disappoint me.
day_3: Halfway. I need results, not excuses.
Three days in. The board is watching our numbers.
We're at the midpoint, {name}. Show me you belong here.
day_4: One day left after today. Give me something I can be proud of.
Tomorrow is the last day. Today decides if there even IS a tomorrow.
The clock is ticking, {name}. Make today count.
day_5: Last day. Everything rides on this.
Final day. No more second chances after this.
It's the last morning. Give me the front page of your life.
warning: We're behind. Every point counts now.
The numbers don't lie, {name}. We need a strong story today.
I can hear Regionbladet's presses from here. Dig deeper.
danger: I'm already writing your termination letter, {name}. Change my mind.
HR called. They want to know when your desk will be free.
The board is meeting this afternoon, {name}. Guess who's on the agenda.

critical: {name}, you know what happens if this continues.
I can't protect you from the board anymore, {name}.
This paper has survived two world wars. I won't let you kill it.
I've seen interns do better. Think about that.
bad: Not enough, {name}. We're losing readers every day.
My grandmother could sell more papers. And she's been dead twelve years.
Regionbladet's editor just sent me a fruit basket. A FRUIT BASKET, {name}.
Close the gap or I'll close your career.
warning: We're still behind. Regionbladet doesn't rest.
Better. But 'better' doesn't sell papers.
I see effort. I need results.
Not bad. Not good either. Keep pushing.
neutral: Adequate. That's the nicest word I'll use.
You survived another day. Don't celebrate.
good: Hmph. Not bad, {name}. Do it again tomorrow.
Don't let it go to your head. One good day means nothing.
The board will notice this. Good.
great: ...Good work. Don't tell anyone I said that.
Regionbladet's editor won't be sleeping well tonight.
If you keep this up, I might actually learn your name.

gameover_fired.text: Pack your things, {name}. I already called the temp agency.
gameover_fired.name: Gunnar Ek

gameover_survived.barely: You survived the week, {name}. Barely. See you Monday — if I don't find someone better.
gameover_survived.decent: Not bad for a Stockholm kid, {name}. You can stay. For now.
gameover_survived.dominant: Hmm. Maybe I was wrong about you, {name}. *looks away* Maybe.
gameover_survived.name: Gunnar Ek

onboarding.intro: Welcome! It's good to have someone young on the team.
onboarding.rules: Every morning you'll find today's leads on the desk. Pick one — just one — and dig.
onboarding.threat: If we fall fifteen points behind Regionbladet... there's no job left.
onboarding.start: Got it? Good. Get to work.

desk_notes.day_1: Sit down. Don't touch anything. And don't smile — this isn't a holiday, {name}.
day_2: Fabriksbladet ran three stories yesterday. We ran one. You want me to do the math for you?
The mill's PR department called to 'welcome' you. That means they already know your name. And not in a good way.
Day two. In this town, day two is when they decide if you're a threat or a punchline. Which is it going to be?
day_3: Halfway through and Fabriksbladet is pulling ahead. I didn't hire you to lose slowly, {name}.
The factory owners are reading our paper now. If the next front page is weak, they'll stop. Permanently.
Midpoint. You've had three days. Show me you've found something or start packing.
day_4: One day left after this. I need a story that makes the factory board choke on their coffee.
Tomorrow's the last edition. If today is mediocre, don't bother coming in tomorrow.
The mill's lawyer called again. Good — that means we're hurting them. Don't stop now.
day_5: Last day. My printer runs at five. Either we have a front page worth reading or we have nothing.
Final edition. Fabriksbladet already printed theirs. Theirs is boring. Ours better not be.
This is it. After today, either this paper survives or I close the doors myself. Your move, {name}.
warning: Fabriksbladet is pulling ahead. You know why? Because they don't have you. That's their advantage right now.
The numbers are slipping. People in this town read the paper that doesn't make them uncomfortable. That's not us. So we need to be BETTER.
We're behind. In Industristad, behind means dead. Not eventually. Now.
danger: The board called. They want to know why we're losing to a glorified factory newsletter. I had no answer, {name}. DO YOU?
Fabriksbladet's editor sent flowers to my office. FLOWERS. I threw them in the bin and thought about throwing you after them.
I've already read your replacement's résumé. Two languages, five years experience, and they don't need hand-holding. Think about that.
default: The mill opens at six. I opened at five. Where were you?
There's a story in this town that could break everything wide open. Find it before Fabriksbladet does.
Fabriksbladet prints what the mill tells them to. We print what the mill doesn't want anyone to read. Get to work.

critical: This is worse than Fabriksbladet. And they literally just reprint the mill's internal memos. You lost to THAT.
I pulled you from Småstad for this? Gunnar must have been desperate to recommend you.
The mill's PR intern writes better copy than this. She's nineteen, {name}.
I don't fire people. I just stop remembering their names. What was yours again?
bad: Not enough. Fabriksbladet didn't even try today and they're STILL winning. Do you understand how embarrassing that is?
The factory workers deserve better than this. I deserve better than this. Even the paper deserves better than this.
Bergström is sleeping like a baby tonight. Because of YOU, {name}.
I've seen more fight in an obituary.
warning: Fabriksbladet is still ahead. They don't have to be good — just safe. We don't get that luxury.
Better. But 'better than yesterday' means nothing when yesterday was a disaster.
I see the effort. I don't care about effort. I care about results.
The mill noticed us today. They laughed. That's not the reaction I wanted.
neutral: Adequate. By Småstad standards. We don't use those standards here.
You survived another day. The mill noticed. They're not impressed. Neither am I.
*lights cigarette, stares at you for an uncomfortable amount of time* ...Fine.
good: Not bad, {name}. The factory floor is reading us. Don't ruin it tomorrow.
Bergström's secretary called to complain. I told her to buy a subscription. That's the only thanks you'll get.
Good work. Don't let it make you lazy. One good day doesn't make a journalist.
Fabriksbladet can't ignore us today. Enjoy it. It won't last if you slack off.
great: ...I almost smiled. Almost. Don't get used to it.
The mill's lawyer called twice. We MUST be doing something right. Or something actionable. Either way — good.
This is why I brought you here. Not for your charm. For THIS. Do it again.
Bergström can't sleep tonight. Good. I haven't slept well in years. Welcome to journalism.

gameover_fired.text: Pack your things. I told Gunnar you weren't ready. He owes me a bottle of brännvin for this waste of my time.
gameover_fired.name: Birgit Ståhl

gameover_survived.barely: You survived. Barely. Don't mistake luck for talent, {name}. This town would have eaten you alive in week two.
gameover_survived.decent: You held your own against a town that breaks people. The board won't fire me this quarter. That's YOUR contribution.
gameover_survived.dominant: You actually did it. Bergström's sweating. The workers are reading us. The mill is scared. *long pause* ...I will deny ever saying this, but — well done.
gameover_survived.name: Birgit Ståhl

onboarding.intro: So you're the one from Småstad. I heard you impressed Gunnar. That won't impress me.
onboarding.rules: Same as before — leads on the desk, pick one, dig. But this town is different. The mill watches everything.
onboarding.threat: Fall fifteen points behind Fabriksbladet and you're done. I don't do second chances.
onboarding.start: This isn't a small-town paper anymore. Get to work.

desk_notes.day_1: The harbor opens at five. I opened at four. Don't be late again, {name}.
day_2: Sjöfartstidningen ran a full spread yesterday. We had a column. Fix it.
A fisherman stopped me at the pier this morning. Asked if we're going to last the week. I said yes. Don't make me a liar.
Day two. The shipping company already knows your name. That's not a compliment.
day_3: Halfway. The harbor doesn't wait for anyone and neither do I.
Three days in. Sjöfartstidningen is buying drinks for the coast guard. We can't compete with money. Compete with truth.
The fishermen are watching, {name}. Either we're their paper or we're nobody's.
day_4: One day left after this. I need something that makes the shipping company sweat.
Tomorrow is the last edition. If today's front page doesn't matter, don't bother printing it.
The tide is turning, {name}. Question is — which way.
day_5: Last day. The sea doesn't give second chances. Neither do I.
Final edition. Make it count or the pier will be quieter tomorrow.
This is it. After today, Kuststad Paper either survives or sinks. Your call, {name}.
warning: We're behind. Sjöfartstidningen doesn't even have to try — the money does the work. We have to be better.
The numbers are sinking. Like everything else in this town.
We're losing ground, {name}. In a harbor town, that means drowning.
danger: The shipping company sent a wreath to the office. A WREATH, {name}. They think we're dead already.
I've sailed through storms that sank bigger boats than this paper. But I can't sail alone. WHERE ARE YOU?
My replacement list has three names on it. Two of them can start Monday. Think about that.
default: The harbor never sleeps. Neither should you.
There's a story buried in every wave that hits this pier. Find one.
Sjöfartstidningen prints what the shipping company tells them. We print what the sea washes up. Get digging.

critical: This is worse than nothing. Even the shipping company's newsletter has more spine.
I pulled you from Industristad for THIS? Birgit must have been relieved to see you go.
The fish market clerk writes better copy. She does it on receipt paper, {name}.
I don't fire people. The sea does it for me. Keep this up and you'll understand what that means.
bad: Not enough. Sjöfartstidningen is printing champagne ads while we're sinking.
The fishermen deserve better. This town deserves better. I certainly deserve better.
The shipping company's PR department called to offer us a subscription to their own paper. As a joke.
I've seen more courage in a barnacle.
warning: Sjöfartstidningen is still ahead. They have money. We have you. That's supposed to be enough.
Better. But 'better than yesterday' doesn't keep a newspaper alive.
I see effort. The harbor doesn't care about effort. It cares about results.
The shipping company noticed us today. They're not worried yet. They should be.
neutral: Tomorrow. Again. The tide waits for nobody.
Adequate. By mainland standards. We're not on the mainland.
You survived another day. The pier is quiet tonight. That's not necessarily good.
good: Not bad, {name}. The fishermen are reading us again. Don't waste it.
The shipping company's lawyer called. I told him to buy a subscription. ...He hung up.
Good work. Don't let the salt air go to your head. One good story doesn't make a journalist.
Sjöfartstidningen can't ignore us today. Enjoy this. It won't last if you stop digging.
great: ...The harbor is talking about us tonight. That's rare. Don't get used to it.
The shipping company filed a complaint. That means we're doing something right. Or something expensive. Either way — good.
This is why I brought you to this coast. Not for the view. For THIS. Again tomorrow.
The old fishermen bought extra copies today. That hasn't happened since '68. *long pause* ...Well done.

gameover_fired.text: Pack your things. I told Birgit you had potential. She'll never let me forget this.
gameover_fired.name: Ragnar Sjöberg

gameover_survived.barely: You survived. Barely. The sea spared you this time, {name}. Don't test it again.
gameover_survived.decent: You held your ground against a town that swallows people whole. The fishermen trust us again. That's YOUR doing.
gameover_survived.dominant: The shipping company is running scared. The coast guard is answering questions. The harbor is honest for the first time in years. *looks out the window* ...I'll deny saying this, but — you belong here.
gameover_survived.name: Ragnar Sjöberg

onboarding.intro: You're from Industristad. Birgit says you can take a hit. We'll see.
onboarding.rules: Same setup — leads on the desk, pick one, dig. But this coast is different. The sea hides everything.
onboarding.threat: Fall behind Sjöfartstidningen and you're done. I don't repeat warnings.
onboarding.start: The harbor is waiting. Get to work.
